I tend to procrastinate a lot, then I have a burst of creativity and start a lot of things. Then I get overwhelmed and I finish none of them and slip back into procrastination. I am scared I will achieve nothing as an artist that way. So my question is: if I were your friend, what would you say to me in this situation?

you are going to feel better once you have proven to yourself that you can finish things. you can work with a list to collect ideas for finishing, but i think the big trick here is to put shorter things on the list. just to help push you over the finish line for a few items. once you have done this i think you will feel like a much more valid person, who can finish stuff

So, how do i meet people and work towards deepening and maintaining a friendship? especially if I'm more of a hermit, lol

begin to collaboritavely analyze your immediate surroundings. for example, if you seem to be in a factory, ask them if they know what kind of factory it is. if you both already know that, then maybe you could begin to speculate how long the factory has been there, or how it was built

Please give us the rest of the factorizing steps!

i can't give them all at once, because there's way too many. but let's pick a random number up to a million and i'll try to tell you the first 3 things i would do. The number we're working with today is 306124. The first thing is, notice it's even. How do we know this? because the last digit is even. so first we gotta cut the whole thing in half. this can be done by slicing it where you see even numbers that you can handle. so for me that's 30 6 12 4. cut those in half, and keep them in the same order, preserving the digits. so that makes 15 3 06 2.... or 153062. Next, notice it's still even. do the same thing again. this gets tricky because you have a lot of consecutive odd numbers in there. cutting numbers in half when they have a lot of odd digits, without paper, can be a little annoying. but if you can handle the 1530, then the 62 part is easy. 1500 in half is 750, plus the 15 is 765. and the 62. so 76531. Now it's odd and you can't divide it anymore. So you can go ahead and put some 2's in your final answer, because you divided it by 2, twice. so you know that your answer is going to include 2 twice. Now, you're left with an odd number: 76531. The next step is to check if it's divisible by 3. The trick for this is, and most people seem to know this trick, if the number is divisible by 3, all the digits are gonna add up to a multiple of 3. so you can group them. so, looking at 76531, .. knock out the 6, i can knock out 7 and 5 (75, mult of 3, or 57, either way, same thing) knock out the 3, ... and you're left with 1 which is non-3. so by knocking out digits and groups of digits which add to 3 or mult of 3, if all the digits got knocked out that way then we know it's a mult of 3, but if we were left with any non-3s, (which we were), then we know it's not a mult of 3. Ok, now the real game begins. We're going to check every other prime number, in ascending order. No need to check 5, because we can see that it's not a multiple of 5 (hopefully you can see that outright ... but the way to tell that is if the last digit is 0 or 5, which it's not). So next we're going to check 7. Every prime we're going to check from here on out will be based on the same system. We're going to manipulate the main number (76531) by adding or subtracting the checker as many times as we want. IF the main number is a mult of 7, then that means we can add or subtract 7 as many times as we want, and it should STILL be a mult of 7. We can ALSO DIVIDE the main number by ANYTHING and it should still be a mult of 7, if it originally was. So basically the idea is to do these manipulations in a way that gets you to something you recognize as a mult of 7 or not. There are many ways of doing this. First, if you want, you can just drop the 7 from the left. because this essentially would mean you're subtracting 70000. which, if the original number was a mult of 7, then it should still be a mult of 7 when you subtract 70000. so we'll knock out the 7, and you have 6531. Next, i'm going to do probably the most common technique, which is to work from the right. Here's an interesting principle: if we've already reduced the main number in the ways we've already reduced it (cut it in half until it's odd, divide by 3 until it's not a mult of 3, divide by 5 until it's not a mult of 5), then THAT MEANS that for ANY future prime number you wanna check, you can ALWAYS cause the number to level off with a zero at the end by either adding or subtracting THE CHECKER OR ITS TRIPLE. That's because all your future prime numbers that you're gonna check are gonna end in either 1,3,7, or 9. So that means those are always either 1 or 3 away from 10. And if you've already reduced your main number properly, then that number will ALSO always be either 1 or 3 away from the nearest 10. So you just pick which maneuver to make based on what you need. So looking at our main number as it stands now, 6531, and if we're checking for 7, i can tell you that what you wanna do is subtract 21. That's how you can get it to level off to a zero at the end. 6510. and of course you can drop the zero, because that does NOT change whether or not the main number is divisible by 7. so that leaves you with 651. the same move again works: subtract 21, gets you to 630 and drop the zero, you have 63. Do you recognize it yet, as something that you know to be a multiple of 7, or something you know to not be a multiple of 7? you might recognize 63 as a multiple of 7. But in case you don't see that, you could make another move, by adding 7, and you get 70, drop the zero, is 7. Now do you recognize it (7) as either being a multiple of 7 or non-multiple of 7? i think you do. So we can confirm that 7 is one of the factors. next comes the not so fun part where you have to actually divide 76531 by 7. then when you get the result, continue working with this new main number, and you also have to check 7 again on that number in case it's in there twice

i hate the designation of autism, because it is a name given to a series of traits that present culture does not understand, and does not fit in with the ridiculousness that has been deemed 'normal'. it is treated as if it were a disease, to be diagnosed, rather than as one way that a person can exist as. the world feels like a narrow obstacle course and i didn't get the instruction pamphlet for the obstacle course that was handed out to everyone else. i sometimes feel like understanding communication is deciphering code and making dangerous assumptions. but i like to be touched and i love eating. i never get 'hyperfixated' (hate the term), i wish i did because that would mean something could interest me for a prolonged period of time, i can't think of anything that has interested me over the course of my life other than maybe videogames, but i spend a lot of my free time laying down and trying to escape the world, which is stressful and scary and overwhelmi ng. and i am socially awkward and i need to sometimes move to calm down and sometimes i just cant remember names and when im with others its like i become them and assume their personalities and have wondered often if i have a personality, seems like i am a blank slate. worst of all, the things that i think are interesting are shameful, when i try to share with others they mock me and call it cringe or weird, i don't know what i am but whatever i am it seems like i came to the wrong party. if i do the things i really wanna do i don't think there is any way i could get money from it, unless i am like amazing at it, even then not much. given the information above, what are some ways i can improve my situation?

How did you learn to factorize big numbers (>1000) in your head? Could you teach me how to do it?

only 1 step at a time. first, i'll tell you how to figure out if a number is even (divisible by 2). if the last digit is even, then the whole number is even. If it's even, divide it by 2, and set the 2 aside as one of the factors for your final answer. to divide a number by 2, try to separate the digits into groups that form numbers you already know how to divide by 2. for example, if you have 1634, ... you can split that into 16 and 34 next to each other. you can safely half each of those, side by side, and keep them next to each other. This is assuming that you already happen to know what 16 divided by 2 is, and what 34 divided by 2 is. If you didn't, then i will go back a couple of steps and just tell you the simple fact that 16 divided by 2 is 8 and 34 divided by 2 is 17. hopefully you can remember that. So you can conclude that 1634 divided by 2 is 817. I got carried away and gave you more like 13 steps instead of 1. i'll try to give fewer steps next time, but i promise to give you all the steps i know, if you want to know them. i apologize if you already knew all of those steps. in case you were looking for something more advanced, i can tell you that 2001 is an awesome checker for both 23 and 29 at the same time

So, based on the music that exists, it is very clear that when lyrics and music work together to form a coherent whole, everything is amplified. Given this fact, it seems silly not to take advantage. But, the issue is, songs are supposed to be fun to listen to. At least I want my songs to be fun to listen to, that way people will want to listen to them while they work and such. But what if I want to write a song about something that is sad? Like, if I wanted to write a song about my dog dying (hypothetically), then the song would have to be slow and loud to match the terrible sadness of the death of my dog, right? But, would that song be fun to listen to? I wouldn't want to do the dishes while listening to a song that makes me feel like my dog died. So, my question is, how do I achieve a balance between lyrical and musical content while ensuring my music is enjoyable? Do I only write songs about things that are good? That seems awfully limiting. I look at th e songs that you make and the songs that other artists make about sad topics and those songs seem to sound happy while talking about things that are sad. Pink Floyd's Time, for example, talks about the stress of getting older and then it rips into a *sick* guitar solo. The thing is, it works really well, even though it doesn't really sound... sad? Like it sounds like how getting older feels, and even though getting older should feel sad, the solo doesn't feel sad, even though the solo sounds like how getting older feels. This appears to conflict with the transitive property. How do you do this?

i think you have received a good hint that writing sad songs with pleasant melodies is powerful. but really, to actually do this stuff (songwriting), it's so delicate that you never know when it's gonna work right. but the more you do it, the more likely it is that you will find yourself in a situation of writing something that really works for you. to open the floodgates a little, try to give yourself a challenge to write something that's not what you mean. songwriting thrives on reverse psychology sometimes. that's because the universe thrives on reverse psychology. why? it's free games, for you and your friends to solve, through tears of joy

how do you decide whether to use uppercase or lowercase letters?

there are many ways, but here are some examples of where i would choose to use capital letters: If i'm starting a new sentence, and i need a little bit of extra conviction, i might use a capital letter to start. if i'm using chord symbols such as Bb. if i'm using acronyms, such as UNESCO. if i'm using the letter L and i feel that it won't be otherwise interpreted as L based on context. i might use them if i need emphasis or power, in the same way that the 'bold' style might be used, except capitals have the advantage of being available in places where bold is not. the value i see in albums is that they are just another level of grouping, just as you could say a song is a grouping of sections, sections are groupings of phrases, phrases are groupings of melodic fragments, melodies are groupings of notes, etc. there's many different ways to analyze the groupings of a song. but anyway, an album is one way to be just one tier above songs in the grouping hierarchy. i tend to like albums that seem to form a coherent and meaningful group of songs, which for me tends not to be about what order they're in as much, unless there is a narrative element. but for me grouping things is always a way to generate new meaning;grouping anything at all creates an opportunity to see what the group means as a whole, and how different aspects of parts of the group contribute to that meaning. maybe you think this does not work particularly well with songs, but for me it sometimes does. i can relate to your experience of liking songs more  when taken one at a time, but there are also important albums to me, that have a meaning in and of themselves as a whole, beyond just one or a small subset of 'good songs' in them. are there any albums like that for you?

To take it back to the root of the problem, the first thing you wanna do if you are working on a computer is: find the Export. Find the feature of your computer that actually makes a video file, in 1 file, such as mp4, that you can play in a video player. Everything else is just working backwards from there, figuring out how to change what video it is. Expand the possibilities 1 step at a time. If your video file starts entirely black, the next thing i can suggest is try to make part of it white. If the whole thing is silent, the next step will be to try to make at least some of it non-silent. and take a picture of yourself doing it so you can remember how simplicity works, in case you find yourself in a complicated emergency later on down the road

Can you expand on this please: "if you can learn to understand the noise, then it will seem calm"? Like if you hear someone banging a wall, how would understanding that noise make it seem calm?

that's what we always do. Actually, our entire existence is making sense of immense noise. the cacophony of electrical signals hitting your brain, the sight and sound, your entire nervous system, .... you are being bombarded by information. it can take a human person at least a couple years just to figure out how to make sense of the basics. to walk, talk, identify objects, etc. But eventually, once you familiarize yourself with those things, they seem normal, and they become part of a normalized baseline state. You'll also notice that when people are sleeping with any type of noise or activity going on, they tend to be more likely to wake up when the noise changes. The more you understand what's making the sounds you're hearing, you can accept them into your reality fairly lovingly
